results.title: [Tony Agapitos: Arrival of the Greek Ship "Patris" at Victoria Dock 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows the arrival of the Greek ship ‘Patris’ to Victoria Dock in 1961 and her passengers coming to Australia to start a new life.

This film is part of a collection of 16mm films made by Tony Agapitos. The collection offers a glimpse at Greek migrant life in Victoria from the 1950s to the 1970s.

results.title: [Orsola: Teramo, 1960]
results.brief_description:
In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico Ciabarra, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine. The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia. The children that appear in the final sequence are related to the filmmaker.

Note: An excerpt from ‘Orsola: Teramo, 1960’ appears in ‘Innamorati’ (2001/3); a four minute digital storytelling work created by Roberta Ciabarra, ACMI Film Programer and daughter of Orsola and Ulderico, as part of a pilot workshop conducted at ACMI in 2001.For technical reasons a re-record of the narration was done in 2003.

Donor has requested that any de-accessioning of the 8mm film that it be returned to him or the family. File Note with Governance.
results.description:
A ‘day in the life’ of a young woman whose fiancé has emigrated to Melbourne, Australia. In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine.

The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia.

The related work “Innamorati” - made by Orsola’s daughter - tells the moving story of Orsola’s marriage and her journey to Australia to be reunited with her husband.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows a glimpse of the royal tour (the Duke of York’s car), followed by scenes of Duigan’s wife Kathleen playing with a child and a dog, including teaching the dog to stand on its hind legs and to jump for a stick.

results.title: RAAF Newsreel. No. 9. Operation sabre ferry
results.creator_credit: Harry Rayner and Australia. Royal Australian Air Force
results.brief_description: Newsreel items including: 1. No. 3 Squadron and No. 77 Squadron of the RAAF ferry the Sabre Jet from the east coast of Australia to Butterworth in Malaya via Townsville, Darwin, Netherlands New Guinea, Philippines, Borneo, Malaya. 2. Firefighter - RAAF demonstrates capability of new firefighting truck. 3. Addition of the new Air to Air Missile to the Sabre Jet Fighter. Test fired at Woomera.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows a group of film competing in a wheelbarrow race (one person holding another’s ankles while they walk with their hands); running; collecting water in a pail; playing with dogs; rowing on a river or lake; and picnicking and lounging on the grass with 1920s cars behind. The film then shows people on a golfcourse and three women and a dog in the gardens of a large home.

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows the Malins family in a montage of holidays and events in Victoria spanning several years from 1946 to the 1950s (not in precise chronological order). Highlights include a visit to Melbourne Zoo, trips to the beach along the Great Ocean Road and to Phillip Island, as well as trips to the snow at Lake Mountain. Malins frequently captured road signs of their travel destinations, including Anglesea, Lorne, Wye River and Cowes. Other moments captured include children’s birthday parties, horse riding and children at school (possibly Koonung Heights Primary School in Mont Albert North, 1954–1993).

The film also features footage of an historic gathering at the Shrine of Remembrance on the occasion of Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery’s visit to Melbourne in 1947.

description_for_label:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows the Malins family in a montage of holidays and events in Victoria spanning several years from 1946 to the 1950s (not in precise chronological order). Highlights include a visit to Melbourne Zoo, trips to the beach along the Great Ocean Road and to Phillip Island, as well as trips to the snow at Lake Mountain. Malins frequently captured road signs of their travel destinations, including Anglesea, Lorne, Wye River and Cowes. Other moments captured include children’s birthday parties, horse riding and children at school (possibly Koonung Heights Primary School in Mont Albert North, 1954–1993).

The film also features footage of an historic gathering at the Shrine of Remembrance on the occasion of Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery’s visit to Melbourne in 1947.

results.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
results.creator_credit: Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja
results.credit_line:
Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Script: Courtney Collins with Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Sound: Left of Elephant Sound

Single-channel video

Approx. 5 mins

Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description:
First Peoples were forcibly moved from their lands into designated camps by European colonists from around 1880 onwards. As a result of the ongoing displacement of First Peoples, Amoonguna was established as a government reserve 21kms from Mparntwe (Alice Springs) in 1963. Known as town camps today, reserves like Amoonguna make up the Alice Springs Aboriginal housing associations. These town camps are home to many artists who are extremely proud of their communities. English is often the third language of Amoonguna residents with the major language groups being Arrernte (pronounced Arenda), Warlpiri and Pitjantjatjara.

Mparntwe is a place where government policy and intervention in First Peoples communities has distinct and obvious implications. The Australian media often portrays this part of the nation negatively, without showing the historical narratives at play or the strength, beauty and talent that comes from the Central Desert. At the centre of the exhibition Two Girls From Amoonguna, is the animated video work Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls, which reminds audiences that Mparntwe is filled with joy and laughter. From camping and travelling to town to finding bush tucker, this place is home.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.

constellations_primary.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_primary.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

results.title: Emulation of Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific for DOS
results.brief_description:
Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific is a war simulation game. In the game, the player takes on the role of the task force commander in the Pacific Theater during World War II. The player can play as both the U.S. and the Japanese Empire in scenarios such as Pearl Harbor, Coral Sea, Midway, Eastern Solomons, Santa Cruz and Philippine Sea. The game is played on a 72x84 hexagonal grid on which different units and squadrons, such as naval vessels and land based aircraft, are positioned. The player chooses actions for these units, the consequences for which are simulated by the computer. The game is quasi real-time, meaning that the game can be paused at any given moment at which time the player can give orders to the units. All interaction with the game is through a menu interface. Orders that can be given to units include strike, escort, transport, support, refuel and more complex maneuvers such as strike routines.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/goldfields/

Last accessed: 6/05/2021

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1984 by Strategic Studies Group

results.title: Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific for DOS
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Two 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, colour map, product registration card, subscription card and manual in a cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific is a war simulation game. In the game, the player takes on the role of the task force commander in the Pacific Theater during World War II. The player can play as both the U.S. and the Japanese Empire in scenarios such as Pearl Harbor, Coral Sea, Midway, Eastern Solomons, Santa Cruz and Philippine Sea. The game is played on a 72x84 hexagonal grid on which different units and squadrons, such as naval vessels and land based aircraft, are positioned. The player chooses actions for these units, the consequences for which are simulated by the computer. The game is quasi real-time, meaning that the game can be paused at any given moment at which time the player can give orders to the units. All interaction with the game is through a menu interface. Orders that can be given to units include strike, escort, transport, support, refuel and more complex maneuvers such as strike routines.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/goldfields/

Last accessed: 6/05/2021

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1984 by Strategic Studies Group

results.title: Play It Again II: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again II project aims to document, preserve, and create an accessible and playable history of Australasian videogames and videogame culture from the 1990s.

This collection comprises physical games and hardware donated to ACMI for the project and as well as game emulation files created by ACMI or harvested from external web repositories.

The project is being undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Swinburne University, RMIT, AARNet, UNESCO PERSIST and OpenSLX GmbHt.
This project is supported by the Australian Government through the Australian Research Council Linkage Program. Play It Again II is a continuation of Play It Again I, which focused on the preservation of Australasian videogames from the 1980’s.
